[h2] I would say it is one of the best sandbox games for now. [/h2]

Despite some rough edges, the breadth of possibilities in this game makes it pretty unique and easily outweighs its downsides. Here you can build almost everything. But the game can't be equally good in all its aspects, right? Regarding vehicles, I can't really recommend trying spacecrafts (and the Space DLC respectively): maybe building and launching them is ok'ish, but everything that relates to orbital mechanics has too many simplifications and its own rules. Not to mention that besides Earth there is only one celestial body ‚Äî the Moon. If you really want a game similar to KSP, then it's not your pick (pay attention to a project called KSA though). Coming down to planes, helis and other flying vehicles, you need to know that aerodynamics here are pretty simplified too. Take-offs and landings are too short, even the biggest of your planes will most likely have a TWR ‚âà 1. In terms of flight model, a game called Flyout, for example, or even SimplePlanes/SimplePlanes 2, does its job better, but it still can be pretty enjoyable in Stormworks. Building land vehicles (cars, trucks (yes, the game gives you a reason to use them. Basically you can try "ETS 2 gameplay" at any moment), trains (yes, they are practical too (and cool, I love trains)) is generally good, but sometimes the two biggest islands (one in the Industrial Frontier DLC) that the game provides can feel a bit empty (there are addons from the Steam Workshop that can fix it though).
The aspect in which the game is almost perfect is marine vehicles. That's the game's origin, and it works the best from my point of view, plus I can't really name a good alternative sandbox game with the same or better quality in sea or underwater gameplay (maybe From the Depths, but idk, haven't followed this game that much).
From what I wrote, you may guess that the game is a hodgepodge of everything with a kinda meh realization, but it's not true. The building from blocks and small parts plus the fact that you play as a character gives you a lot more immersive feel compared to other games, where you can only play as the "creation" itself (I mean by that SimplePlanes 1, KSP, From the Depths etc.), and that's where Stormworks earns its additional points for me personally. However, what really distinguishes it from other games is the so-called "logic", thanks to which it's possible to create something truly complex, and that is what gives so much depth to your creations. It can be a little harsh at the beginning, but after all it's maybe the best part of the game.
There is a career mode too, which is already good for a sandbox game (two modes actually, with a lack of customisation for me, but the already mentioned addons can fix it), not something extraordinary, but you definitely can spend several dozen hours there.

In conclusion, I can only say that Stormworks, at least for me personally, deserves the title of one of the best sandbox games :)

Probably some of the most fun I had building engine configurations and vehicles.
Lots of nuance for how different things effect the performance of any given design.
If you're looking for a sandbox to build cool vehicles in with a shocking level of depth, this game has it.
If you're looking for something with a decent career mode, this ain't it.
The fun is mostly found in building things like actual diesel-electric power systems for trains/boats, gearboxes with finely tuned gear ratios, low level logic controllers for handling everything from engine ignition to clutch control and gearing, and mechanical systems to handle tasks like mining, logistics, oil drilling/processing, and so on. 
The problems are that multiplayer has desync issues, performance is pretty poor, career mode is a long series of randomly generated quests, bad AI, and an overall lack of depth or direction to career mode.
Like space engineers if you added daily quests and greatly expanded on the finer details in ship building.
Makes me wish there were something like it that was a bit more stable, performant, and with a more developed career mode and better enemy AI, I could picture me and a few m8s sinking hours into something like that just running tanker ships around and fighting off the occasional hostile.

Stormworks is still being updated, but it already offers a huge amount of content and freedom.

If you enjoy engineering, problem-solving, and creative gameplay, Stormworks is a great game to dive into.

This game really is one of a kind when it comes to sandbox vehicle building games. Really thought this game would be my first 1k+ hour game, but it fell short really fast as the developers focused on adding features rather than fixing the major issues plaguing the game. On top of lack of fixes and excessive feature updates, the developers constantly share photos of player creations that could never be built naturally in the game without modifying the game files, which is essentially false advertisement.

This game suffers major performance issues, poorly designed physics (they released an update that makes it so you configure the physics because they couldn't be bothered with finding a solution to the complaints) and dlcs that have nothing to do with the title of the game ("build and RESCUE").

I feel like any fun I have with this game is always in spite of the game itself.

There is no tutorial for anything outside of a 4 year old YouTube playlist that only goes over basic engines and logic, there is no documentation of what worldgen variables do outside of vague descriptions, career mode quests constantly break to the point that to have a cohesive experience with it you basically need to play in the creative mode with all the cheats turned off so that you can debug the game in real time. I submitted a bug report over a month ago, uploaded my save and everything. It has received no response. At time of writing there are 429 open tickets on the issue tracker with the oldest ones being over 4 years old. I can appreciate that the dev team is still active so long after 1.0 but it is baffling how much they focus on adding new content over making any of the content they already have function properly, documentation of game features, basic QoL, or even just a complete tutorial.

I can only recommend this game if you want a vehicle sandbox where you spawn in and mess around with stuff off the workshop, or if you have a huge amount of tenacity and drive to curate your own experience and set your own goals with the fragments of a functional game that are present. This is factorio without any tutorial, no item encyclopedia, three arbitrarily distinct gamemodes in place of being able to select specific difficulty settings at world-gen (a research tree and the ability to fast travel are mutually exclusive unless you want to play creative or edit xml files), massively increased jank and lack of QoL (for example wheels cannot have their input directions changed, this means if you assemble wheels in the formation commonly found on something called a car, the wheels on each side will turn (yaw) in opposite directions because you flipped one side. If you mirror that side's wheels they will now spin (pitch) backwards. The only way to fix this is to add a logic element that changes the input sent to the wheels on one side from positive to negative. Instead of just being able to change which way a wheel spins or turns when powered.), and of course just as many bugs. You can still get to space, and you might even find it kind of rewarding in the end, but it's still going to suck for 95% of the time. Not the "I'm being challenged" kind of suck, but the "I have been trawling through two year old reddit posts to figure out how this game feature is supposed to work" kind of suck.

I cannot see the vast majority of people who get this game for anything other than a workshop vehicle sandbox enjoying it, so I do not recommend this game.
